subsection.p: A fractured group of planes representing a range of different divergent futures and pasts. Forming one of the largest sets of known planes, and the origin of mankind. Hopefully, at least one of these planes is familar to the reader.

Anuywn, sometimes called Faeire, the Wylds or Nilfholme is the plane of the fey lords and their kith. It is a vast, highly magick, wilderness. Anuwyn is highly congruent with the mortal realms. In a few places it is possible to cross from the mortal realms into Anuwyn and back again without magical assistance.

The fey lords are fickle, vituperative, highly magical, and very long lived. Their two great Queens are practically demigods. The fey are divided into three factions: those that support the Summer Queen and her Seelie, or Summer, Court, those that support the Winter Queen and her Unseelie, or Winter, Court, and the neutral masses trying to avoid slaughter. For the most part these courts coexist in a tense detente, but periodically pitched battles break out between the two sides. The reason for this conflict has been lost in the mists of time.

Goblins are one of the races of the lesser fey. From them sprang the Orcs of the Mortal Realms a magically fused hybrid of goblin and man who exhibit the worst features of both races. Similarly the Elves are the offspring of humans and the fey lords.
The shadow realms are a mirror plane of the mortal realms. In the shadow realms there is no warmth, there is no joy. Light itself has been bastardized.
The Demimonde is a demonic plane ruled by der Frosch. It is a twisted pocket dimension where the Frosh Lords rule over currate

A pocket dimension that forms a bridge between the Mortal Realms and The Maelstrom realms of Fire and Earth. The City of Brass sits on an island in a sea of lava on a flat world in the Ether. It is ruled by the Efreet and is populated by a range of races including the Djinn. It is a central hub of trade between planes with the main items of trade being precious metals, gems, metalwork, slaves and other delicacies.
The Maelstrom is a world of powerful elemental forces it is the source of elemental potential.

A pocket plane of knowledge resembling a large, dark library. Entry to the plane is usually via a library or book. Many delve here for answers there are here. But most do not return. See The Stygian Library by Emmy 'Cavegirl' Allen for more details.

A non-euclidean plane of death. The inhabitants live in a kind of purgatory state. Churned mud and swampland stretches out into the gloom. Thick fog hangs heavy in the air. Rolling barrows loom out of the murk. A strange root writhes underfoot. A thousand years after the defeat of Napoleon at the Battle of Austerlitz, the world has fallen into decay. Endless war has led to technology stagnating, and beautiful countrysides have been ground to a thick ruin under the boots of a million dead men.

Now, nothing grows. A bizarre and horrible root covers the land; strangling the life from the trees, poisoning the water, and filling the sky with an acrid mist. Humanity barely endures by harvesting this disgusting tuber. It twists their bodies and minds. It infests their thoughts with divine visions of lost vegetables.

Bizarre religious orders have formed. They stockpile abandoned weapons unearthed by the twisting roots. Marching in column under fluttering banners, brandishing mud-clogged muskets and rusted bayonets, they are cruel parodies of long-forgotten armies on the march
For more information see the works of Max FitzGerald and his Turnip28 wargame.
